text: You're practicing levitation spells in the courtyard of Thornwood Academy when the sky turns black. Students around you gasp and point upward. A massive shadow dragon descends through storm clouds, breathing darkness and flame. Malachar the Dread. The ancient beast was imprisoned centuries ago, but somehow he's free. Archmage Aldric, your beloved teacher, rushes forward with a shield of light. The two clash in a battle of magic and fury. But Malachar is too powerful. The dragon seizes Aldric in his claws and takes flight. As they disappear into the storm, something falls from the sky and lands at your feet—Aldric's enchanted compass, glowing faintly and pointing north toward the Blackspine Mountains.

If you cast a flight spell and chase aft.text: You don't hesitate. You channel your magic and launch yourself into the air, racing after Malachar. Wind tears at your robes as you climb higher into the storm clouds. The dragon is ahead, a dark silhouette against lightning. You shout Aldric's name. Malachar turns his massive head and locks eyes with you. For a moment, you see amusement in his gaze. Then he roars—a sound that shakes your bones. You ready your wand, heart pounding. This is it. You have two options: attack with everything you have to force him to drop Aldric, or follow from a distance and learn where his lair is hidden.

If you blast him with lightning bolts to.text: You raise your wand and scream the words. Lightning erupts from your wand in brilliant arcs, striking Malachar's wings—the spell drains your energy rapidly. The dragon shrieks and wheels around, furious. "Foolish child!" his voice booms in your mind. He releases Aldric momentarily to swat at you with one massive claw. You fire a force blast—more energy consumed—but it barely slows him. You dodge but another strike connects, sending you spinning through the air. You try to recover but you're falling, plummeting toward the ground below, your magical reserves nearly depleted. The academy grounds rush up at you. You have seconds to act—cast a shield charm to survive the fall, or use your remaining energy for one last desperate attack on the dragon.

If you cast a shield charm to survive th.text: You twist in the air and channel every ounce of magic into a shield. The spell wraps around you just before impact. You hit the courtyard hard, the shield absorbing most of the force but not all. Pain explodes through your body. Students rush to you, their faces blurred. Healers arrive. [BREAK] You wake three days later in the infirmary, bandaged and aching. Professor Nightshade sits beside your bed. "Brave, but reckless," she says. "Malachar nearly killed you. If you want to save Aldric, you'll need more than courage. You'll need knowledge." She leans closer. "There's a section of the library that's forbidden to students. Black magic texts. One of them might help." Your choice: sneak into the forbidden library tonight, or ask Headmaster Thornwick for permission first.

If you sneak into the forbidden library.text: Midnight. You slip through the empty halls, wand lit. The forbidden section is locked behind iron gates with magical wards. You whisper an unlocking charm you learned in second year. The gates swing open silently. Inside, ancient tomes line the shelves—dark covers, strange symbols. You search for hours until you find it: the Codex Umbra. Black magic. Your hands tremble as you open it. Inside, an imprisonment spell capable of binding even dragons. But it requires three components: a hair of a medusa, the fang of a vampire, and the heart of an iron golem. Dangerous creatures, deadly quests. You memorize the ritual and slip out before dawn. Do you set out alone immediately, or tell your best friend Luca about this and ask him to join your dangerous journey?

If you memorize the spell and set out to.text: You can't waste time with permissions and debates. Aldric is dying, his magic draining away. You pack supplies, take your wand, and leave at dawn through the academy's hidden exit. The compass points north, but first you need those components. According to your studies, a medusa dwells in the Petrified Gardens to the east. You'll start there. [BREAK] Two days of travel through dark forests and across a rushing river bring you to the Gardens. Stone statues fill the landscape—victims of the medusa's gaze. The air smells of death. You hear hissing ahead. Between the statues, you glimpse her: serpents writhing where hair should be, skin pale as marble. You have a mirror shield in one hand, sword in the other, or you could try a sleeping spell first.

If you approach with your mirror shield.text: You raise the mirror shield and advance slowly, watching her reflection. She senses you and turns, her gaze meeting the mirror. You see her confusion. She reaches out with clawed hands. You duck under her grasp, get close, and with lightning speed slash your sword—cutting a single serpent hair. She screams. "THIEF!" Her serpents hiss and she raises her clawed hand. A lightning bolt erupts from her palm, striking your shield. The mirror shatters into pieces. The entire garden seems to wake. Stone statues tremble. The medusa lunges at you. You sprint toward the crumbling east wall, the hair clutched in your fist. Behind you, her footsteps and furious hissing. The wall has a gap—you can squeeze through. Do you run through the maze toward that exit, or turn and duel her with your eyes closed?

If you run through the statue maze towar.text: You dodge between statues, heart hammering. She's right behind you, shrieking curses. You cast a speed spell—magic surges through your legs, draining your energy but propelling you forward faster. A stone warrior's arm blocks your path—you vault over it. The gap in the wall is ahead. Ten feet. Five. You dive through just as her claws rake the air where you were. You tumble into grass on the other side, gasping, your magical reserves depleted. You rest briefly to recover your strength. One component down, two to go. [BREAK] According to your research, a vampire lord dwells in the Crypts of Ashenvale, just hours away. You travel quickly and reach the ancient cemetery at dusk. Crumbling tombstones, dead trees, and a mausoleum with a heavy stone door. The dying light casts long shadows. You push the door open and descend stone steps. Darkness swallows you. The legends at the academy warned that this vampire can turn himself invisible. You recall your training—you can cast a spell to see invisible creatures and light your wand to navigate, or cast see-in-darkness to move without drawing attention. But you haven't mastered casting two "see" spells simultaneously. Which approach do you choose?

If you cast see-invisible-creatures and.text: You whisper the incantation for seeing invisible creatures, feeling magic drain from you. Then you light your wand dimly—just enough to navigate. The crypt reveals itself: coffins lining the walls, cobwebs thick as curtains. At the far end, on a stone throne, sits a figure—pale skin, sharp features, dressed in black. His eyes snap open, glowing red. He's visible. Good. "A visitor," the vampire lord says, his voice smooth. "How delightful. I can smell your fear, young wizard." He rises, fangs visible. "You've come for my fang, haven't you? I can sense dark magic on you." He moves closer with inhuman speed. You have two options: cast a sleeping spell to subdue him, or channel the costly, energy-consuming sunlight spell that will drain you significantly but guarantee you can extract his fang safely. Choose quickly—he's advancing.

If you channel a costly, energy-consumin.text: You plant your feet and channel everything into the sunlight spell. Your wand erupts with brilliant golden light, filling the crypt like dawn itself. The vampire screams, his flesh smoking. He lunges at you—you fire a force blast from your wand, consuming more energy, throwing him backward. He stumbles, clawing at his face. You advance, maintaining the sunlight spell even as your energy drains dangerously low. He falls to his knees. "Mercy," he rasps. You collapse the spell, nearly depleted. You rush forward, pulling a dagger. With precision, you extract one of his fangs. He howls but is too weakened to stop you. You pocket the fang and stumble out of the crypt, utterly exhausted. You rest for an hour to recover your magical reserves. Two components down. [BREAK] The iron golem foundry is hidden deep in the Blackspine Mountains. You travel for days, the compass guiding you north. Finally, you descend into an abandoned factory. Massive furnaces, rusted gears, and patrolling golems—ten feet tall, made of iron, glowing runes on their chests. You need one's heart. Do you lure a golem into a furnace to weaken it, or use electromagnetic magic to overload its core?

If you lure a golem into the furnace to.text: You spot a lone golem near a massive furnace. You fire an explosion spell across the room—the blast consumes energy but gets the golem's attention. Its head swivels and it charges toward you, heavy footsteps shaking the ground. You cast a speed spell and sprint toward the furnace, magic draining with each boost. At the last second you dive aside, energy nearly depleted. The golem can't stop. It crashes into the furnace, metal screeching. The heat makes it glow red. You gather your remaining strength and blast it with a force spell. Its chest cracks open, revealing a glowing crystal heart. You reach in, ignoring the burns, and rip it free. The golem collapses. You rest to recover your magical reserves. You have all three components. [BREAK] Following Aldric's compass, you travel north to the Shadow Fortress—a black castle carved into the Blackspine Mountains. Cultists patrol the entrance. Torches flicker. You could turn invisible and slip past the guards, or steal a cultist robe and disguise yourself. Which approach feels safer to you?

If you cast an invisibility spell and sl.text: You whisper the invisibility charm and fade from sight. Heart pounding, you walk past the cultists. One turns as if sensing something, but sees nothing. Inside, the fortress is dark stone corridors lit by green torches. You follow the sound of chanting deeper into the fortress. [BREAK] You reach a massive chamber. In the center, Aldric is strapped to a dark apparatus—chains and glowing runes. His face is gaunt, his magic visibly draining into a crystal above him. Malachar isn't here yet. You could place the three components immediately and begin the ritual, or you could first try to reverse the draining apparatus to restore some of Aldric's strength. But reversing it might take time you don't have. What do you choose?

If you immediately place the three compo.text: You arrange the three components in a triangle around yourself: medusa hair, vampire fang, golem heart. You open the Codex Umbra and begin the incantation. Dark energy swirls around you. The air crackles. Aldric's eyes flutter open. "No," he whispers weakly. "Don't use black magic..." But you continue. The chamber trembles. Suddenly, the wall explodes inward. Malachar bursts through, massive and furious. "YOU DARE?" his voice thunders in your mind. He lunges at you, jaws open. You hold your focus and keep chanting the ancient words. Shadow magic pours from you. Malachar's claws slash the air inches from your face. You have two critical choices: hold focus and complete the binding incantation as written, or try to absorb some of Malachar's stolen magic to strengthen the spell and guarantee success. The second option might save you, but at what cost?

If you hold focus and complete the bindi.text: You ignore Malachar's attacks and speak the final words. The components ignite with black flame. Chains of shadow erupt from the ground and wrap around the dragon. He roars, thrashing, but the chains tighten. With a blinding flash, he's pulled into an obsidian prison—a black crystal that forms around him. Silence. You've done it. You rush to Aldric and free him from the apparatus. He's weak but alive. "You used black magic," he says sadly. "I know," you reply. As you help him stand, you feel it—a dark stain inside you, a whisper of shadow that will never leave. You saved your teacher, but the black magic has marked your soul permanently. Together, you escape the collapsing fortress and return to Thornwood Academy as heroes. But you'll never be the same.

If you try to absorb some of Malachar's.text: Greed takes hold. You alter the incantation mid-spell, reaching out to absorb the magic Malachar has stolen. Power floods into you—incredible, intoxicating. But it's too much. The ritual spirals out of control. Black energy explodes outward. Malachar shrieks as he's pulled into the obsidian prison, but you're pulled in with him. The last thing you see is Aldric's horrified face before darkness consumes you. You're trapped inside the crystal with the dragon, conscious but unable to move or speak, for all eternity. The academy buries the crystal deep underground. No one knows you're still aware inside, screaming silently. Forever.

If you try to negotiate with Malachar mi.text: Mid-spell, an idea strikes you. What if you could bind Malachar AND absorb just enough magic to save Aldric faster? You speak to the dragon. "Stop! I can offer you partial freedom—a smaller prison, some autonomy—if you release Aldric's magic now." Malachar pauses, considering. "Interesting. You'd bargain with me?" You complete a modified version of the ritual. The dragon is bound, but not fully—he exists in a half-prison state, able to communicate but not escape. Aldric lives but is weakened permanently. You become the crystal's warden, forever monitoring Malachar's prison. The dragon whispers to you at night, slowly corrupting your thoughts. You saved Aldric, but at what cost? Years pass. You're never quite yourself again.

If you first attempt to reverse the drai.text: You rush to the apparatus controls, trying to decipher the runes. Your fingers trace patterns, attempting to reverse the flow. The crystal above Aldric flickers. "Hurry," he gasps. You pull a lever. The apparatus shudders—and explodes. Energy blasts you backward. Aldric screams as the chains tighten, draining him faster. The door crashes open. Malachar enters, slow and confident. "Foolish child. You've accelerated his death." You scramble for the components to start the ritual, but the dragon's claw pins you to the ground. "Too late." His jaws open. You hear Aldric's final breath as your world goes dark. You tried to save him, but your hesitation doomed you both.

If you steal a cultist robe from a suppl.text: You circle the fortress and find a supply wagon. You knock out a lone cultist and steal his robe. The disguise is perfect. You walk through the front gates, nodding at guards. Inside, you navigate corridors until you reach the draining chamber. Aldric is there, chained. You're about to approach when a voice behind you says, "You there. New recruit?" You turn. A cultist is staring at you suspiciously. Your face doesn't match any he knows. "Intruder!" he shouts. Alarms blare. Guards flood the room. You try to fight but you're overwhelmed. They drag you to Malachar. The dragon grins. "Another snack." His jaws snap shut. The disguise failed. You're dead.

If you use electromagnetic magic to over.text: You target the nearest golem and cast an electromagnetic pulse. Lightning arcs from your wand, wrapping around the golem's body. Its runes glow brighter, brighter—then it explodes. Shrapnel flies everywhere. A shard of iron embeds in your shoulder. You cry out in pain. Other golems turn toward you, alerted by the noise. Three of them advance. You're injured and surrounded. You try to run but they're faster. One swings its massive fist. You see it coming but can't dodge. Impact. Everything goes black. You're dead. The electromagnetic approach was too loud, too dangerous. You should have used the furnace.

If you cast a sleeping spell to subdue h.text: You quickly cast a sleeping spell. Purple mist flows from your wand toward the vampire. He inhales it and laughs. "You think such weak magic can affect me? I've lived for centuries, child." The spell does nothing. He moves with supernatural speed, appearing before you in an instant. His hand grips your throat, lifting you off the ground. "You'll make a fine thrall," he whispers, fangs descending toward your neck. You struggle but his strength is overwhelming. The bite is cold, draining. Your vision fades. When you wake, you're one of his servants—a vampire spawn, cursed to serve him forever. You never save Aldric. You never complete your quest. You're damned.

If you cast see-in-darkness to move with.text: You whisper the see-in-darkness incantation, feeling magic flow through your eyes. Suddenly, the crypt becomes clear as day—every coffin, every cobweb visible. You move silently forward, keeping your wand dark. At the far end, you see an empty stone throne. Strange. Where is the vampire? You scan the chamber. Nothing. You step closer to the throne, heart racing. Then you feel it—cold breath on your neck. "Foolish choice, young wizard," a voice whispers behind you. Before you can turn, icy hands grip your shoulders. The vampire was invisible the entire time. His fangs pierce your neck. You try to scream but darkness floods your mind. [BREAK] When you wake, you're different. Pale. Cold. Hungry. The vampire lord smiles. "Welcome to eternity, my newest spawn." You're cursed to serve him forever in these crypts, feeding on travelers who stumble into your domain. You never save Aldric. You never complete your quest. You're damned to an undead existence, forever.

If you turn and duel the medusa with you.text: You spin around, squeezing your eyes shut, and raise your wand. You hear her approaching. You fire a stunning spell in her direction, the magic draining your energy. You hear her dodge. You cast a fire bolt—it consumes more energy but you hear it miss. Fighting blind is impossible. She's circling you now, hissing. You cast wildly, desperately, your reserves depleting rapidly. Nothing connects. Her claw rakes across your arm—burning pain. You stumble, nearly out of magic. "Open your eyes, little wizard," she taunts. "Look at me." You know if you do, you'll turn to stone. But you can't fight her blind. In desperation, you open your eyes for just a split second to aim. That's all it takes. Her gaze meets yours. Cold spreads through your body. You can't move. Your skin hardens. Stone. You're another statue in her garden forever.

If you cast a powerful sleeping spell on.text: You raise your wand and whisper the sleeping incantation. Purple mist flows toward the medusa. She sniffs the air suspiciously. The mist envelops her. She sways. "What... what have you..." Her eyes droop. She collapses among the statues, snoring. Success! You approach carefully, eyes averted. You pluck a serpent hair from her head. She doesn't stir. [BREAK] But as you turn to leave, she wakes with a furious screech. "THIEF!" The spell wasn't strong enough—she was only dazed for a moment. She lunges, faster than before. Her gaze locks with yours before you can look away. Cold spreads through your body. No. Not like this. Your last thought freezes with you. You're stone. Forever another victim in the Petrified Gardens. The sleeping spell failed.

If you tell your best friend Luca to joi.text: You trust Luca with everything. You meet him at dawn and show him the Codex Umbra. "We can save Aldric together," you say. His eyes widen. "Black magic? Are you insane?" He backs away. "We need to tell someone. The Headmaster. An adult." You grab his arm. "There's no time! Aldric is dying!" But Luca shakes his head. "I can't let you do this. I'm sorry." He runs off. [BREAK] Within the hour, Headmaster Thornwick summons you. Luca told him everything. The Codex is confiscated. You're confined to your dormitory while they organize a proper rescue team. Two weeks pass. Then the devastating news arrives: Aldric is dead. Malachar drained him completely. You're crushed. Luca avoided you, guilt-ridden. Your friendship is destroyed. If only you'd gone alone instead of trusting him. His betrayal cost everything.

If you ask Headmaster Thornwick for perm.text: You go straight to Headmaster Thornwick and tell him you need access to the forbidden section to save Aldric. He listens gravely. "I understand your desperation, but that section is forbidden for good reason. Black magic corrupts everyone who touches it." You argue, plead, but he's unmovable. "We'll organize a proper rescue mission with experienced wizards. Give us time." Weeks pass while they plan and prepare. [BREAK] Then the news comes: Aldric is dead. Malachar drained all his magic and has grown even more powerful. The dragon now terrorizes villages across the kingdom. You're crushed with guilt and rage. If only you'd acted immediately instead of following rules. Thornwick's bureaucracy killed your teacher. You drop out of Thornwood Academy, unable to forgive yourself or the headmaster. You wander as a failed wizard, haunted by what could have been.

If you launch one final desperate flame.text: You ignore the ground rushing toward you and focus all your remaining energy into one massive fire spell. Every last drop of magic pours into your wand. Flames erupt in a column of heat and fury, striking Malachar directly in the chest—your reserves completely drained. The dragon roars in pain. For a moment, you feel triumph. Then you hit the ground. No shield, no protection, no energy left. The impact kills you instantly. Students rush to your broken body. Malachar flies away with Aldric, injured but alive. Your sacrifice wounded the dragon but saved no one. You're dead. The academy holds a funeral honoring your bravery, but it's small comfort to your grieving family. Aldric dies three days later in Malachar's lair, his magic drained completely. Your desperate attack achieved nothing.

If you follow at a distance to learn whe.text: You decide stealth is wiser than confrontation. You hang back in the clouds, following the dark silhouette of Malachar as he flies north. Hours pass. Your arms ache from maintaining the flight spell. The landscape below changes from green forests to gray mountains. Finally, Malachar descends toward a black fortress carved into a mountain peak—the Shadow Fortress. You memorize the location and turn back toward the academy. [BREAK] When you land, you're exhausted but you have crucial information. You report to Headmaster Thornwick. He's impressed. "Good work. We'll organize a rescue team immediately." But organizing takes time. Days turn into weeks as they gather powerful wizards, plan the assault, debate strategies. Meanwhile, Aldric is dying. You grow frustrated with the delays. Do you wait for the official team, or sneak away and attempt the rescue alone?

If you wait for the official rescue team.text: You wait. And wait. Two weeks pass. The rescue team is finally ready—twelve powerful wizards, all prepared to assault the Shadow Fortress. You travel together, reaching the fortress at dawn. But when you storm inside and reach the draining chamber, you find only Aldric's corpse. You're too late. Malachar has already drained him completely and fled. The dragon is now unstoppable, having absorbed Aldric's immense power. He goes on to conquer three kingdoms before anyone can stop him. You're alive, but you failed. Aldric is dead because you waited instead of acting. The guilt never leaves you. You become a broken wizard, drinking to forget your failure. The official team's caution cost everything.

If you sneak away and attempt the rescue.text: You can't wait any longer. One night, you sneak out of the academy and travel north alone. You reach the Shadow Fortress in three days, exhausted and under-supplied. The fortress is heavily guarded. You have no plan, no backup. You try to sneak in but a patrol spots you. Alarms blare. Guards surround you. You fight desperately but you're outnumbered and exhausted. A cultist's spell hits you square in the chest. You fall. They drag you before Malachar. "Another fool," the dragon rumbles. His jaws open wide. At least you tried. At least you didn't wait. But you're still dead. Aldric dies alone in the fortress days later. Your solo rescue attempt was brave but doomed from the start.

If you convince a few trusted friends to.text: You gather three of your closest friends—fellow students who also love Archmage Aldric. Together, you sneak out and travel to the Shadow Fortress. You're young, inexperienced, but determined. You infiltrate the fortress, covering each other. You reach the draining chamber where Aldric is held. But you're too inexperienced, too loud. Alarms blare. Cultists flood the room. You fight desperately, but you're just students facing trained dark wizards. One by one, your friends fall. You watch them die trying to protect you. A dark spell hits you in the chest. You collapse. The last thing you see is Malachar entering the chamber. "Foolish children," he rumbles. "You should have sent adults." His claw crushes you. Everyone dies. Aldric dies. Your friends die. All because you were too impatient to wait for proper help.

If you rush to the academy armory to gat.text: You sprint to the academy armory while chaos erupts around you. You grab what you can—a silver dagger, protective amulets, healing potions. Armed now, you rush back toward where Malachar flew. But minutes have passed. The dragon is gone. You clutch Aldric's compass—it points north. You've lost precious time. [BREAK] "Wait!" a voice calls. Professor Corvus approaches, the academy's expert on ancient dragon lore. Silver-haired, green-robed, eyes gleaming with urgency. "I know how to save Archmage Aldric," he says breathlessly. "There's a binding ritual that can trap Malachar. But we need three components quickly: phoenix tears from the Ember Peaks, moonstone from the Whispering Caves, and starlight essence from the Crystal Spire. I'll guide you. We must hurry!" Do you trust him and accept his help?

If you accept Professor Corvus's help an.text: "Yes! Please, help me save him," you say desperately. Corvus smiles—something flickers in his eyes, too quick to read. "Excellent. Time is short. The phoenix tears are closest—in the Ember Peaks, two days east. The phoenix nests in volcanic caverns. Dangerous, but you're brave." He hands you a crystal vial and a map. "Collect the tears when the phoenix weeps at dawn. Go now!" [BREAK] You travel quickly, reaching the volcanic peaks at dawn. Heat shimmers off black rock. You hear a haunting cry—the phoenix. You climb toward the sound and find her: magnificent, wreathed in flame, weeping golden tears into a pool of lava. The tears evaporate unless collected immediately. You cast a cooling spell to approach the lava pool, energy draining. How do you collect the tears?

If you use the crystal vial to scoop the.text: You maintain the cooling spell—magic draining steadily—and reach toward the lava with the crystal vial. The heat is intense despite your spell. You scoop golden tears just as they hit the lava surface. The vial fills with glowing liquid. Success! The phoenix looks at you, curious but not hostile. You back away carefully. [BREAK] You return to the academy. Corvus is waiting, eyes bright. "Excellent work! One down, two to go. Next: the Whispering Caves for moonstone. It grows deep underground where no light reaches. But beware—the caves are home to shadow wraiths. They feed on fear." He hands you a lantern. "This will help." You travel for days to the Whispering Caves. At the entrance, darkness beckons. You light the lantern and descend. Whispers surround you immediately. How do you proceed?

If you follow the lantern light and igno.text: You focus on the lantern, pushing deeper. The whispers grow louder—promises, threats, memories. You ignore them. Hours pass. Then you see it: moonstone, glowing faintly on the cavern wall. You cast a breaking spell, draining energy, and extract a chunk. The moment you touch it, shadow wraiths materialize—formless, hungry. You fire a light spell, scattering them temporarily. You cast a speed spell and sprint toward the exit, energy depleting rapidly. You burst into daylight, gasping. You rest to recover your magical reserves. Two components secured. [BREAK] Corvus meets you again. "Brilliant! One more: starlight essence from the Crystal Spire. It's the most dangerous. The spire is guarded by enchanted crystal golems. But I believe in you." You reach the Crystal Spire after three days. It rises like a shard of glass into the sky. Do you climb the exterior or find an entrance?

If you climb the exterior using levitati.text: You cast a levitation spell and begin ascending the smooth crystal surface, magic flowing from you with each boost upward. Halfway up, a crystal golem detaches from the wall—ten feet tall, transparent, deadly. It swings a massive fist. You dodge, nearly losing your grip. You fire a force blast, consuming more energy. The golem cracks but doesn't fall. You push higher, exhausted. At the top, starlight essence pools in a crystal basin. You collect it in a vial. Three components secured. [BREAK] You return to Corvus, triumphant. He's in his office with the other two components. "You've done it! Now we can perform the ritual and save Aldric!" He takes all three components. His expression shifts—cold, calculating. "Actually, these aren't for saving anyone. They're for Malachar's ascension ritual. I've been serving him for years. And you... you've been so helpful." He casts a binding spell. Chains of magic wrap around you. What do you do?

If you try to break free with a powerful.text: You gather your remaining strength and cast a dispelling charm. Energy pours from you. The chains flicker but hold. Corvus laughs. "Admirable, but futile." He gestures and the chains tighten, crushing the air from your lungs. "Malachar will drain Aldric's power, then use these components to become immortal. You'll watch from the dungeon." He drags you to the fortress dungeons and throws you into a cell. The door slams. [BREAK] Hours pass. You're alone in darkness. But you notice something—the cell's lock is old, rusted. You still have a bit of magic left. You cast a weak unlocking spell, draining your last reserves. The lock clicks. You're free. You sneak through corridors toward where you sense powerful magic. You find the ritual chamber. Corvus and Malachar are there, the components arranged around Aldric's unconscious body. Do you attack or try to disrupt the ritual?

If you disrupt the ritual by destroying.text: You fire a spell at the moonstone, shattering it. The ritual circle explodes with light. Malachar roars. "NO!" Corvus turns, furious. "You fool! You've destabilized everything!" The components react violently—phoenix tears ignite, starlight essence burns. Energy spirals out of control. You see Aldric stirring. You rush to him. "The ritual—it's collapsing! We have to go!" But Malachar lunges at you. You push Aldric aside. "Run!" you shout. Malachar's claw pierces your chest. Pain explodes. But the ritual energy reaches critical mass. The explosion consumes everything—Malachar, Corvus, you. [BREAK] When the dust settles, Aldric finds your body. You're gone. But so is Malachar. You sacrificed yourself and saved everyone. Aldric returns to the academy, heartbroken but alive. Your name becomes legend. The student who killed the unkillable dragon.

If you attack Corvus directly to stop hi.text: You fire a stunning spell at Corvus. He deflects it easily. "Pathetic." Malachar turns, sees you. The dragon's claw sweeps across the room faster than you can dodge. It hits you square in the chest, crushing bone. You fly backward into the wall. Pain. Darkness. Your vision fades. You hear Aldric scream your name. But you can't move. The last thing you see is Malachar's jaws opening. Then nothing. You're dead. The ritual continues. Malachar becomes immortal. You failed everyone. Corvus's betrayal was complete, and your reckless attack sealed your fate and Aldric's.

If you accept defeat and stay in the cel.text: You sit in the darkness, defeated. Hours turn to days. You hear distant roars, explosions. Then silence. [BREAK] Eventually, someone opens your cell—a member of the academy rescue team. "We found you! But... I'm sorry. Aldric is dead. Malachar completed his ritual. He's more powerful than ever. Professor Corvus was revealed as a traitor. We barely escaped alive." You leave the dungeon, broken. You failed. Aldric is dead because you trusted the wrong person. Malachar now terrorizes the entire realm, nearly unstoppable. You live with the guilt forever. Every choice you made led to this disaster. The weight of your failure crushes you daily. You drop out of the academy, unable to face anyone. You wander, haunted by what could have been.

If you try to find an entrance at the ba.text: You search the base of the spire for an entrance. You find a crystal door, locked with magical runes. You cast an unlocking spell—it drains energy but the door opens. Inside, a spiral staircase ascends into darkness. You climb. Crystal golems activate as you pass, pursuing you. You cast a barrier spell to slow them, magic depleting rapidly. At the top, you grab the starlight essence. But the golems corner you. You fight desperately, firing spell after spell, but there are too many. A golem's fist connects with your head. Everything goes black. You never wake up. The golems drag your body away. You're dead. Climbing the outside would have been faster, safer. Aldric dies in captivity. Malachar wins.

If you light your wand and try to commun.text: You light your wand brightly and speak into the darkness. "I mean no harm. I only need moonstone to save someone." The whispers intensify, overlapping, angry. The shadow wraiths don't care about your intentions. They swarm you, dozens of formless shapes. You feel their cold touch draining your life force. You try to cast a protective spell but you're already too weak. The darkness consumes you. Your last thought is of Aldric, dying alone. You collapse. The wraiths feed. You're dead. Never try to reason with creatures of pure shadow. They understand only hunger. Aldric dies in Malachar's fortress. The dragon grows unstoppable. Your naivety killed you and doomed everyone.

If you try to approach the phoenix direc.text: You approach the phoenix without the cooling spell, arms outstretched. "Please, I need your tears to save my teacher." The phoenix looks at you—and unleashes a wave of flame. You cast a shield spell desperately but the heat is too intense. Your shield shatters. The fire consumes you. You scream. Your skin burns. Everything goes white, then black. You're dead. Phoenixes are not negotiators. They are creatures of pure fire, indifferent to mortal pleas. You should have used the cooling spell and taken the tears quickly. Now Aldric dies in Malachar's fortress, his magic drained completely. Your foolish approach to the phoenix cost everything.

If you decline Corvus's offer and search.text: Something about Corvus feels wrong. His eagerness, the gleam in his eyes. "Thank you, Professor, but I'll find my own way to save Aldric." Corvus's expression darkens for just a moment. "Are you certain? Time is running out." You nod. "I'm certain." You turn and leave. [BREAK] You spend days researching alternative methods. But nothing is powerful enough. Weeks pass. Then the news arrives: Archmage Aldric is dead. Malachar drained his magic completely. Worse—you learn that Professor Corvus was arrested. He was a spy for Malachar all along. The components he wanted you to gather were for a dark ritual to make the dragon immortal. Your instincts saved you from betrayal, but not Aldric. You failed to act quickly enough. The guilt haunts you forever. Sometimes the safe choice isn't the right choice.
